question: [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Function: start_viewer_in_memory()] [Panic Safety] If a panic occurs during TUI rendering after line 47, will cleanup code run to restore terminal state, or will the terminal remain in an unusable state? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Test: verify_tool()] [Fuzz Testing] Has the bytecode deserialization path been fuzz-tested with malformed inputs, or could there be crash bugs or vulnerabilities in handling malicious bytecode that the single test doesn't cover? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Struct: BytecodeViewerConfig] [CLI Injection] Can attackers inject malicious arguments via the clap Parser at lines 23-37 to override intended paths or inject unexpected command-line flags? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Struct: BytecodeViewerConfig] [Short Flag Conflicts] Could the short flags -b and -s at lines 27 and 35 conflict with other tools or flags if this viewer is integrated into a larger CLI application? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [General] [Production Misuse] If this development tool is accidentally deployed to production validator nodes, could attackers exploit it to view sensitive bytecode, cause DoS via crafted files, or exhaust resources? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [General] [Privilege Escalation] If the viewer runs with elevated privileges, could file read vulnerabilities be exploited to read sensitive system files like validator keys or configuration files? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [General] [Access Control] Is there any access control on which users can run this tool, or can any user with system access view arbitrary Move bytecode files? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Function: start_viewer()] [Empty Files] How does the viewer handle empty bytecode files or files with only header data - does it panic, hang, or gracefully handle the edge case? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Function: start_viewer()] [Truncated Files] Can truncated or partially written bytecode files cause deserialization to read beyond buffer bounds or enter infinite loops? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Function: start_viewer_in_memory()] [Large Modules] For extremely large compiled modules with thousands of functions, does the viewer handle performance degradation gracefully, or can it become unresponsive? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Function: start_viewer()] [Binary Garbage] If provided with completely random binary data instead of valid bytecode, does the deserializer at line 54-55 safely reject it, or can it enter unexpected code paths? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Function: start_viewer()] [Path Separator] Are Windows-style path separators (backslash) properly handled on Unix systems and vice versa, or can path parsing issues cause security vulnerabilities? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Function: start_viewer()] [File Encoding] Does fs::read() handle different file system encodings correctly, or can encoding mismatches cause data corruption when reading bytecode files? (Low)
